JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, APRIL 1, 1955

Council Debates Plan
For Tour Of Russia
Pros and cons of sending a Hopkins student on a tour of Russia
this summer were discussed by the
Student Council at their regular
noon-hour meeting last Monday in
the Levering Hall Board Room.
The meeting was chaired by SC
vice-president Herb Belgrad in the
absence of president Jim Phinney.
No decision was made, however,
because of the lack of a quorum.
Discussion was also held on the
saine topic at the previous Friday
evening meeting of the SC, but
then too a lack of a quorum (12
Members) stymied decision.
The idea of sending a Hopkins
Student to tour Russia was suggested by a recent letter to the
SC and to the News-Letter from
the Oberlin College Student Council. The Oberlin students are coordinating an intercollegiate project aimed at providing a delegation
of American college students with
the opportunity of travel in the
USSR this summer.

tour to the student body. According to Gordon and Lupovich, most
of the individuals polled further
stated that they each would be
"willing to donate one or two dollars, depending on who goes."
Belgrad then pointed out that
the proposed tour would offer a
worthy Hopkins student with a
unique educational experience and
that the Oberlin letter had no
"political" overtones, whereupon,
sophomore class representative
Don Gallagher interjected, saying
that he felt the proposed tour was
not at all educational, adding,
"You can bet they'll (the American
students) only get a mouthful of
propaganda."

Homewood, Baltimore, April I, 1955

APO Scouts Dorms Food Boss Plans Innovation SC Considers
Leads Off Fund Drive At Dormitory Dining Rooms Russian Tour
The blood types of Hopkins dormitory students are being sought
by the national service fraternity,
Alpha Phi Omega, in order to
make the donation of blood from
Hopkins more efficient, in case of
a future emergency, committee
chairman Philip Rierson announced.
Although plans for organizing
the blood types of Hopkins students had been under consideration
since last fall, it was not until
several students donated blood to a
St. Joseph's Hospital patient on
March 10 that the drive was actually begun.
Nearly one hundred and twentyfive people have agreed to give
blood, according to Rierson, who
stated that the project had met
with "very good response". The
names collected will be given to sev-

Annual Concert
Draws Gate Of 600

An estimated 600 persons were
present last Friday, March 25, at
the annual band concert held in
Shriver Hall.
"The first band concert ever to
be held in Shriver Hall was a great
success", stated Fred Blackburn,
president of the band. He further
stated "The only improvement
possible is that of making the concert longer." ,

Other events planned for this
season are: a home concert with the
Glee Club on April 30, a concert
at Swarthmore College on May 6,
and a concert on the Gilman Hall
steps as part of Homecoming
activities on May 15, according to

Al Hlavin Stands Out Jay Stickmen Clash Wednesday
In JHU Track Plans With Crimson In Curtain Raiser
The JHU Varsity and Freshman
track squads in preparation for
home meets.this weekend opened
their practice season last Friday
afternoon with a triangle meet
against Towson and Western
Maryland on a cold, windswept
Western
Maryland field. The
Marylanders won, compiling 491
/
4
points, while the Hopkins teams
placed second and fourth, with 43%
and 14 points respectively.
Coach John Bridgers,' stating
that "the teams did as well as was
expected," was rather pleased, and
even elated, over the showings of
a few Jay men. Al Hlavin, varsity
co-captain, whom the coach singled
out as "our probable high-scorer
for the season," ran three fine
races. He won the low hurdles from
a Towson boy who placed fourth
in the Mason-Dixon finals in 1954,
copped a second in the high hurdles
and a third in the broad jump,
compiling 10 points.
Sam Wright, who took top honors in the 330, fourth in the shotput, and another fourth in the
220, and Jim Love, who won both
the shot and discus, were other
JHU standouts. Led by Love, who

Bilgrav's Blue Jays
Meet Mules Today
Team Still Unsettled
With one regularly scheduled
game under its belts, the Blue Jay
Varsity baseball team takes on
Muhlenburg today in a practice
game at Hopkins.
Yesterday the „Jays opened their
regular season by playing Massachusetts Institute of Technology
at Hopkins. The touring MIT nine
was an unknown. quantity to Bob
Bilgrav, the JHU mentor, and he
had to send his team into the contest with a minimum of practice.
The Jays had played only one
intrasquad game and two practice
games with Baltimore University
prior to yesterday's game.
Because of bad weather, Bilgrav
has not made his final cut. This
mainly affects the pitching staff
and the outfield. The infield is
set with John Newton at first
base, Jerry Carr at second, Charley
Wyble at third, and Loren Cox at
shortstop. Barrie Wood seems to be
the number one catcher at the
moment according to Bilgrav. In
the outfield, Rowland King is set in
right field. Center field will probably be held down by Don Stoneseifer, but the left field spot is
a question mark with Walt Radek,
a pitcher, and Dick Mercer vying
for that berth. The pitching staff
is very much up in the air because none of the pitchers have
been able to show much of their
stuff.
As to the general outlook of
the team, Bilgrav rates King and
Newton as his most cottsistent
hitters and feels that the power on
the club will come from those two
plus Wood. The team doesn't have
much speed in Bilgrav's estimation
and so he won't have a "running
team" nor will it bunt a lot.
"We need a lot of work in the
infield on double plays and slowhit balls. We are exceptionally
weak on team play, that is on such
things as whether the first or second basemen should field - the ball
and backing each other up," said
Bilgrav about his infield. Bilgrav
continued, "Our outfielders should
be good, for all of them seem to
possess. strong arms, especially
King, Radek, and Stoneseifer.
Mercer is a converted first baseman, but I think that he has a
strong enough arm."

Bridgers spoke of as a "big, powerful guy, who will show some rapid
improvement once his form improves," the Jays took one, two,
three, in the discus. Ray May, who
has had no previous track experience, tied for second with a 5'4"
high jump, and also tied for second in the pole vault.
The Frosh runners showed
some prowess in a few of the
events. Though they all were running against varsity men, Jon
Berry won his heat in the low hurdles, Trenholm copped a third in
the three-quarter mile and a fourth
in the 660, Robin Caples won two
very close thirds in the 220 and
330 yard sprints,- and Pinky
Holmes took third in the onehalf
mile run. Bridgers hopes that
Holmes can stay with the early
pace, because the freshman has a
strong final kick which keeps him
in contention. The coach regards
him not only as a fine varsity
prospect, but also, "one of the
best half-mile prospects Hopkins
has ever had."

What young people are doing at General Electric
the University of New Memico, Class of 1945,
joined General Electric after a year
in the Navy,completed our Advanced
Engineering Program in 1950.
TED ZWICKY, B. S. in EE from

Young engineer
is responsible for
design analysis
of $3,000,000
turbine-generators
The average large steam turbine-generator
costs $3,000,000 and takes two years to build.
It is one of the biggest pieces of electrical
equipment made. Yet its thousands of parts
aKe put together as carefully as a fine watch.
Even a small change in design can affect the
stresses and vibration of the turbine, and
the way it performs. At General Electric,
several men share the responsibility of predicting those effects before the turbine is
built. One of them is 29-year-old E. E.
Zwicky, Jr.
His job: analytical engineer
Here's what Ted Zwicky does. He takes
a proposed mechanical design feature, describes it mathematically, breaks it down
into digestible bits, modifies it, and feeds it
to electronic computers. (It may take two
months to set up a problem; the computers
usually solve it in twenty minutes.) Then
Zwicky takes the answers from the computers, translates and interprets them so they
can be followed by design engineers.
23,000 college graduates at General Electric
This is a responsible job. Zwicky was readied
for it in a careful program of development.
Like Zwicky, each of our 23,000 collegegraduate employees is given a chance to find
the work he does best and to realize his full
potential. For General Electric believes this:
When young minds are given freedom to
make progress, everybody benefits—the individual, the company, and the country.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, APRIL 1, 1955

Council Debates Plan
For Tour Of Russia
Pros and cons of sending a Hopkins student on a tour of Russia
this summer were discussed by the
Student Council at their regular
noon-hour meeting last Monday in
the Levering Hall Board Room.
The meeting was chaired by SC
vice-president Herb Belgrad in the
absence of president Jim Phinney.
No decision was made, however,
because of the lack of a quorum.
Discussion was also held on the
saine topic at the previous Friday
evening meeting of the SC, but
then too a lack of a quorum (12
Members) stymied decision.
The idea of sending a Hopkins
Student to tour Russia was suggested by a recent letter to the
SC and to the News-Letter from
the Oberlin College Student Council. The Oberlin students are coordinating an intercollegiate project aimed at providing a delegation
of American college students with
the opportunity of travel in the
USSR this summer.

Belgrad then pointed out that
the proposed tour would offer a

that the Oberlin letter had no

that he felt the proposed tour was

"You can bet they'll (the American
students) only get a mouthful of
propaganda."

Al Hlavin Stands Out Jay Stickmen Clash Wednesday
In JHU Track Plans With Crimson In Curtain Raiser
The JHU Varsity and Freshman
track squads in preparation for
home meets.this weekend opened
their practice season last Friday
afternoon with a triangle meet
against Towson and Western
Maryland on a cold, windswept
Western
Maryland field. The
Marylanders won, compiling 491
/
4
points, while the Hopkins teams
placed second and fourth, with 43%
and 14 points respectively.
Coach John Bridgers,' stating
that "the teams did as well as was
expected," was rather pleased, and
even elated, over the showings of
a few Jay men. Al Hlavin, varsity
co-captain, whom the coach singled
out as "our probable high-scorer
for the season," ran three fine
races. He won the low hurdles from
a Towson boy who placed fourth
in the Mason-Dixon finals in 1954,
copped a second in the high hurdles
and a third in the broad jump,
compiling 10 points.
Sam Wright, who took top honors in the 330, fourth in the shotput, and another fourth in the
220, and Jim Love, who won both
the shot and discus, were other
JHU standouts. Led by Love, who

Bilgrav's Blue Jays
Meet Mules Today
Team Still Unsettled
With one regularly scheduled
game under its belts, the Blue Jay
Varsity baseball team takes on
Muhlenburg today in a practice
game at Hopkins.
Yesterday the „Jays opened their
regular season by playing Massachusetts Institute of Technology
at Hopkins. The touring MIT nine
was an unknown. quantity to Bob
Bilgrav, the JHU mentor, and he
had to send his team into the contest with a minimum of practice.
The Jays had played only one
intrasquad game and two practice
games with Baltimore University
prior to yesterday's game.
Because of bad weather, Bilgrav
has not made his final cut. This
mainly affects the pitching staff
and the outfield. The infield is
set with John Newton at first
base, Jerry Carr at second, Charley
Wyble at third, and Loren Cox at
shortstop. Barrie Wood seems to be
the number one catcher at the
moment according to Bilgrav. In
the outfield, Rowland King is set in
right field. Center field will probably be held down by Don Stoneseifer, but the left field spot is
a question mark with Walt Radek,
a pitcher, and Dick Mercer vying
for that berth. The pitching staff
is very much up in the air because none of the pitchers have
been able to show much of their
stuff.
As to the general outlook of
the team, Bilgrav rates King and
Newton as his most cottsistent
hitters and feels that the power on
the club will come from those two
plus Wood. The team doesn't have
much speed in Bilgrav's estimation
and so he won't have a "running
team" nor will it bunt a lot.
"We need a lot of work in the
infield on double plays and slowhit balls. We are exceptionally
weak on team play, that is on such
things as whether the first or second basemen should field - the ball
and backing each other up," said
Bilgrav about his infield. Bilgrav
continued, "Our outfielders should
be good, for all of them seem to
possess. strong arms, especially
King, Radek, and Stoneseifer.
Mercer is a converted first baseman, but I think that he has a
strong enough arm."

Bridgers spoke of as a "big, powerful guy, who will show some rapid
improvement once his form improves," the Jays took one, two,
three, in the discus. Ray May, who
has had no previous track experience, tied for second with a 5'4"
high jump, and also tied for second in the pole vault.
The Frosh runners showed
some prowess in a few of the
events. Though they all were running against varsity men, Jon
Berry won his heat in the low hurdles, Trenholm copped a third in
the three-quarter mile and a fourth
in the 660, Robin Caples won two
very close thirds in the 220 and
330 yard sprints,- and Pinky
Holmes took third in the onehalf
mile run. Bridgers hopes that
Holmes can stay with the early
pace, because the freshman has a
strong final kick which keeps him
in contention. The coach regards
him not only as a fine varsity
prospect, but also, "one of the
best half-mile prospects Hopkins
has ever had."

What young people are doing at General Electric
the University of New Memico, Class of 1945,
joined General Electric after a year
in the Navy,completed our Advanced
Engineering Program in 1950.
TED ZWICKY, B. S. in EE from

Young engineer
is responsible for
design analysis
of $3,000,000
turbine-generators
The average large steam turbine-generator
costs $3,000,000 and takes two years to build.
It is one of the biggest pieces of electrical
equipment made. Yet its thousands of parts
aKe put together as carefully as a fine watch.
Even a small change in design can affect the
stresses and vibration of the turbine, and
the way it performs. At General Electric,
several men share the responsibility of predicting those effects before the turbine is
built. One of them is 29-year-old E. E.
Zwicky, Jr.
His job: analytical engineer
Here's what Ted Zwicky does. He takes
a proposed mechanical design feature, describes it mathematically, breaks it down
into digestible bits, modifies it, and feeds it
to electronic computers. (It may take two
months to set up a problem; the computers
usually solve it in twenty minutes.) Then
Zwicky takes the answers from the computers, translates and interprets them so they
can be followed by design engineers.
23,000 college graduates at General Electric
This is a responsible job. Zwicky was readied
for it in a careful program of development.
Like Zwicky, each of our 23,000 collegegraduate employees is given a chance to find
the work he does best and to realize his full
potential. For General Electric believes this:
When young minds are given freedom to
make progress, everybody benefits—the individual, the company, and the country.
